block.p: LEAD: International A3-19 The Communist Party is unraveling in the Soviet Union as President Mikhail Gorbachev has been using his diplomatic skills to stabilize the situation in Europe. Page A1 Mikhail Gorbachev's biggest test of power is his campaign to end a shortage of consumer goods, not the threat of political opposition, he told President Bush at Malta.

LEAD: International A3-19 The Communist Party is unraveling in the Soviet Union as President Mikhail Gorbachev has been using his diplomatic skills to stabilize the situation in Europe. Page A1 Mikhail Gorbachev's biggest test of power is his campaign to end a shortage of consumer goods, not the threat of political opposition, he told President Bush at Malta.

International A3-19 The Communist Party is unraveling in the Soviet Union as President Mikhail Gorbachev has been using his diplomatic skills to stabilize the situation in Europe. Page A1 Mikhail Gorbachev's biggest test of power is his campaign to end a shortage of consumer goods, not the threat of political opposition, he told President Bush at Malta. A1 Gorbachev said to seek end of naval nuclear weapons A16 Rifts within the Western alliance, particularly over German reunification and European integration, have appeared following the rapid pace of change in Eastern Europe. A16 Czechoslovak Communist leaders agreed to accept a minority role in one of the country's two principal regional governments. Opposition leaders said the move could set a precedent. A18 Civic Forum: Politics on a shoestring A18 Erich Honecker is under house, as are other top East German officials in his fallen leadership. A furious, impatient public has taken the hunt for corrupt former officials into its own hands. A1 Kremlin faults Kohl's plan A19 East Germany remains silent on brutality against protesters A19 Leipzig: Where indignation transforms German politics A19 Manila has become a divided city. Its financial center is paralyzed the coup attempt against President Aquino's Government, but most of the city goes about its business. A cease-fire was called to evacuate foreigners trapped in hotels. A1 News analysis: Corazon Aquino seems to have survived the most serious coup attempt of her four years in office, but some of her proudest achievements may not. A8 India's Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, named 15 people to his Cabinet, but he did not announce which positions they would hold. A7 Artillery and rocket duels in Beirut shattered a 10-week cease-fire. The fighting between rival Muslim and Christian factions did not appear to involve Syrian units or Christian forces defending the Presidential Palace. A3 Arabs at U.N. relax stand on P.L.O. A3 The prospect of famine in Kabul hangs over war-battered Afghanis as winter approaches. Efforts to blockade the capital by the Muslim rebels have squeezed up prices of essential items. A11 American is charged in El Salvador with terrorism A6 Drug War stalled in two key countries: Peru and Bolivia A13 The world faces an ecological crisis that violates human rights, said Pope John Paul II. The ''right to a safe environment'' is at root ''a moral issue,'' he said. A14 Bush proposing talks in U.S. on global warming A15 Japan's police subdue Airport protesters with cages A9 National A20-29, B10-13 The investigation of Alan Cranston has widened, focusing on the activities and financing of three voter-registration groups backed by the California legislator. A1 Most savings institutions meet new U.S. standards D1 Washington Talk: The issue haunting Congress is ethics A20 Government areas prone to abuse and mismanagement have been identified by the Office of Management and Budget. The list of 78 high-risk areas focuses especially on contracting, credit plans and financial accounting. A24 Medicare refunds due on surtax, not flat premiums A20 Gifts to Nancy Reagan stir I.R.S. interest in high fashion A20 Government can be sued for interfering in labor talks A22 Georgia's courts facing a change A22 The AIDS drug AZT causes cancer in laboratory animals, the drug's manufacturer said. But doctors say that AIDS patients should continue to take the drug. risks. A20 Big tax increases in Massachusetts are the explosive topic of this week's discussions at the State House. Last week a $1.2 billion package of tax increases self-destructed. A23 10,000 jobs to be cut by I.B.M. D1 Study challenges high-rise safety in Los Angeles basin A25 Regional B1-9 David Dinkins chose six appointees to fill important positions at the center of his new administration: four deputy mayors, a corporation counsel and a press secretary, members of his transition team said. A1 Dinkins asking donors to pay for his inaugural B8 Mayor Koch defended his tenure, advised his successor to bravely face New York City's fiscal problems and attacked the Federal Government. His remarks came in what amounted to a political valedictory. B1 Albany's figures show budget shortfall could hit $500 million B3 A small drawing branded as racist has created an angry debate at the New School for Social Research: Was an instructor's defacement of the caricature a legitimate protest or unjustified censorship? B1 A vocal critic of the school system in New York City was appointed deputy chancellor and chief operating officer by the future Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez. B1 Greenwich's School Superintendent will receive a $200,000 loan from pri-vate investors to help buy a home. The money is part of an innovative plan devised by the school board to attract out-of-town candidates for the post. B1 Advisory board for Jersey City schools is named B2 U.S. refuses private plan to take over Albany airport B2 Fighting ads that hit you right in the nose B3 Axelrod adopts panel's finding on Zion death B4 Congressional subcommittee is reviewing rail-car contract B5 Neediest Cases B5
